Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A syntactically annotated corpus of Appalachian English

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to create an online corpus of one million words of traditional Appalachian speech, which will be freely available to the scholarly community and to the public. Though often socially stigmatized, Appalachian English is historically central to the development of American English from its British origins, and the project aims to provide a resource unprecedented in scope and in public accessibility for cultural, historical, and linguistic research on the English of Appalachia.

The project is based on an existing collection of recordings and transcripts by Prof. Michael Montgomery, a recognized authority in the field, and its goals include digitizing the recordings, aligning the digitized sound files with the transcripts, and annotating the transcripts with detailed grammatical information. Digitizing the recordings will preserve this valuable cultural resource for future generations, and aligning the digitized recordings with the transcripts will allow researchers to rapidly find recorded words and phrases by searching the transcribed text. The grammatical annotation will allow in-depth analyses of particular constructions that are specific to Appalachian English or typical of vernacular American speech more generally, as well as comparisons of Appalachian English with contemporary standard American English, with other vernacular Englishes, and with earlier stages of the language.

Because the corpus will be large, publicly available, and searchable online with standard computational tools, it will foster replicability, thereby contributing to increased empirical rigor in linguistic research. These same properties will also make it possible to use the corpus as a teaching tool at the high school and college levels. It will also serve as a model for the creation of similar corpora of other varieties of English. In sum, the annotated corpus of Appalachian English will deepen our understanding of America's linguistic heritage and promote a scientifically informed appreciation of regional language and culture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative research project has been to create a one-million word corpus of vernacular speech, with transcriptions that are (a) time-aligned with the underlying speech signal and (b) grammatically annotated. The speech underlying the transcripts is from oral history recordings housed at various colleges and institutions in the Southern Appalachians (Eastern Kentucky, Northeastern Tennessee, Southwestern Virginia, and Western North Carolina). The resulting research tool, the Audio-Aligned and Parsed Corpus of Appalachian English (AAPCAppE), is unprecedented in nature and scope, and it will be available to the public as an online resource by the conclusion of the project period of associated Collaborative Research Project #BCS-1152148 (PI Tortora, College of Staten Island, City University of New York). The following URL provides further information and updates:

http://csivc.csi.cuny.edu/aapcappe/

The structure of the AAPCAppE makes it a tool that promises to have great impact on scholarly research, and also more broadly. The time-aligned nature of the transcripts allows researchers to rapidly find desired parts of the speech signal by automatically searching for particular words through the text; the grammatical annotation allows the corpus user to find, count, and statistically analyze syntactic configurations of any type. Both of these features allow for novel and increasingly important approaches to research on language variation and language change. Given the topics of conversation in the oral history interviews chosen for the AAPCAppE (e.g., coal-mining, union organization, hunting, herbal healing, midwifery, farming, cooking, canning and preserving food, education, and race relations), the AAPCAppE is also a highly useful resource for scholars studying the language, culture, and society of a region central to American social and political history. Finally, the AAPCAppE can serve as a novel analytical tool for educators and their students: Language Arts teachers will be able to engage their students in explorations of the historical importance of Appalachian English (and of dialect diversity in the United States more generally) and at the same time train them in grammatical analysis.
